thread.title: Tech commit arrested on organized crime, vehicle burglary charges
thread.title_full: Texas Tech commit arrested on organized crime, vehicle burglary charges | Dallas Morning News

author: Tommy Magelssen
title: Tech commit arrested on organized crime, vehicle burglary charges
text:
Texas Tech football commit Emoree Keshaun Giddens was one of three teenagers arrested this month on organized crime and vehicle burglary charges in Lubbock, according to an online crime report.
Giddens, 17, and the two other teens allegedly broke into a vehicle Oct. 4 in Lubbock and stole a tree rope and seat swing, according to the report. The vehicle's owner chased the three away with a warning shot from a shotgun fired at the ground from the balcony of his apartment, Lubbock police spokesman Lt. Ray Mendoza said.
They were arrested shortly after, according to police, and booked into the Lubbock County Jail.
The story was first reported by the Lubbock Avalanche-Journal.
The two-star recruit is a senior at Lubbock Coronado, where he plays primarily on the offensive line. The class-of-2016 recruit is orally committed to Texas Tech. Oral commitments are non-binding.
Coronado head football coach Seth Parr told the Avalanche-Journal that Giddens was not present at the Mustangs' most recent game, though he is still on the team.
Giddens, along with Stefan Jordan Cordova, 17, and an unnamed person under 17, were arrested shortly after the alleged burglary, according to police records.
Both Giddens and Cordova were charged with organized crime, an enhancement to the burglary charge, Mendoza said. The state penal code defines as "three or more persons who collaborate in carrying on criminal activities." The Avalanche-Journal reports the charge is closed, though the Class A Misdemeanor charge of vehicular burglary is still open.
